column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

The continued large supply of cattle resulted in 1423 cattle penned in a prime only sale.  Quality improved on last sale with increased numbers of prime yearlings, heavy prime bullocks and cows. The regular buyer panel was bolstered by two southern processors and feeders along with opportunity restockers and one live exporter. Cattle were drawn from Mt Isa to Normanton, east to Mt Garnet and south to The Belyando and local area.

The additional buyer demand saw values improve for most categories, with quality a factor. Prime yearlings lifted 49c to 60c, bullocks increased 35c, medium weight cows lifted up to 23c and heavy bulls averaged 25c to 50c higher.

Good quality prime yearling steers to processors sold to 254c, those to feed averaged 272c/kg. Prime yearling heifers to slaughter made from 220c to 248c/kg. Grown steers above 400kg to feed reached 262c to average 238c, processor types sold to 270c to average 249c/kg. Grown heifers to the trade made to 246c, averaging 210c to 231c/kg.

Heavy young bullocks to export slaughter topped at 266c to average 257c, full mouthed bullocks averaged 247c/kg. Lightweight restocker cows averaged 156c to 179c, 2 score cows to processors averaged 186c, selling to 198c. Medium weight 3 score cows sold to 228c to average 212c to 218c, a good sample of prime heavyweight 3 and 4 score cows topped at 228c to average 224c/kg.
Medium weight bulls to live export sold to 264c to average 249c and heavy bulls to processors made to 248c to average 236c/kg.

A special store sale on Friday has 3200 cattle booked.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham
